Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Constructal Theory after 20 Years of Exploration and what the Future Holds?

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Workshop is dedicated to the Constructal Law, a new physics theory emanating from the contemplation of how natural systems evolve in time, and its implications to thermal transport processes. The forming of river basins, the shaping of mammal lungs, the percolation paths of coffee brewing, the growth of tree roots and branches, the complexity of blood vessel networks, all have similarities in their evolution: to exist, it seems, they must morph toward structures that facilitate access to what flows. The bringing together of thermal transport processes experts in Constructal Law is paramount to measure the impact so far of this new law in thermal transport processes, to determine how it can better contribute to the thermal transport knowledge base, and to identify how this area will evolve in the near future as to guide its dissemination. It is also an opportunity for the community to organize and plan around constructal law.

The observations of natural systems resulting in the constructal law can be applied to engineering systems as well, to anticipate how complex thermal transport systems should evolve so they continue to exist. This concept is intrinsically related to the Thermodynamics of energy and entropy balances, via the work (energy) needed to flow and the dissipating heat resulting from it. Diffusion, convection, and radiation are also intrinsically related to constructal law, as they are the most important heat and mass transport processes affecting thermal systems. The contributions of each in new thermal transport processes should not be dictated by materials or manufacturing limitations alone, but should also account for how they will contribute to facilitating access to what flows. The new paradigm born out of constructal law is for the thermal designer not to avoid geometric complexity; rather, to embrace and explore it, to recognize the importance of new form-function relationships as to facilitate access to what flows. The main outcome of this workshop is expected to be a clear direction of constructal law and its implications to thermal transport processes.

Institution.Name: Villanova University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VILLANOVA UNIVERSITY IN THE STATE OF PENNSYLVANIA

POR.DRECONTENT:
Accomplishments

This workshop aimed to advance and accelerate our understanding of biomimetic studies, including constructal theory, through the synergistic interaction among scientific explorations and industrial applications for new frontiers.

Major Activities:

This workshop sponsored by the National Science Foundation and Villanova University was held on April 17-18, 2018. The workshop brought together a multi-disciplinary group of experts to shape the vision of the future of biomimetic researches, including Constructal theory, and determine a comprehensive set of research needs for its continuing advance. The workshop has worked with Franklin Institute to disseminate the results and findings from this workshop to general public through interactive exhibitions.

Specific Objectives:

This workshop was divided into four research topic areas with a diverse set of experts in each area. Each session had a distinct focus with a very engaged audience discussion regarding the four questions as listed below. The answers to the questions are reflected in the research needs brought up in discussions that took place during the breakout sessions.

1. What is the state of understanding in the area of biomimetic engineering?

2. How to illustrate the biomimetic, including constructal, framework in your context? Give a brief example, if possible.

3. What are the identified impacts that have been made because of the biomimetic engineering, including constructal theory, in your areas? These can be technical, societal, organizational, political, etc.

4. What are possible weaknesses, or additional physics, verification data, technical content you believe is needed, to advance your areas in the biomimetic, including constructal, context?

 Significant Results:

This workshop reviewed accomplishments that have emerged from first 20-years exploration of constructal theory, identified new scientific opportunities for further theoretical advances in biomimetic engineering, examined how to effectively utilize the biomimetic concept, including constructal theory, with new materials-innovation infrastructure, and discussed challenges in achieving the vision of accelerating the impact on industry and the nation's economy. This day-and-a-half workshop included leaders from industry and academia to discuss the state-of-the-art and possible future use of biomimetic, including constructal, theory and design to improve the health and well-being of the world’s population relative to energy, infrastructure, and water. Key research and engineering areas included heat and energy, water supply, biology, and health science disciplines. The workshop brought together experts across various fields to provide a focused effort in identify promising, key areas of future research.

 Key outcomes or other achievements:

A written report on the workshop and results disseminations in various venues to the general public and experts in the biomimetic fields.

What opportunities for training and professional development has the project provided?

This workshop has created opportunities for students, teachers, engineers, and professors to participate in the discussions and presentations of various fields within the scope of biomimetic engineering, which offer licensed Professional Engineer training and professional development for engineers, and educational events for students and teachers.

 How have the results been disseminated to communities of interest?

The results of this workshop have been disseminated to communities of interest by a technical report to NSF which is open to all, a website with all the content open to all, presentations of the workshop in conferences, and an educational program at Franklin Institute Museum for broader impacts.

Products:

Journals:  one paper has been accepted to publish on International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer

Thesis/Dissertations:  one Master’s thesis in progress

Conference Papers and Presentations: Three have been accepted in conferences

Websites: https://www1.villanova.edu/content/dam/villanova/engineering/documents/WorkshopAgenda.pdf

Other Products: one hands-on exhibition and one interactive simulation activity, both collaborating with Franklin Institute Museum

Participants:

Franklin Institute Museum, Philadelphia, collaborating on exhibitions for general public and K-12 education.

What is the impact on the development of the principal discipline(s) of the project?

            This workshop reviewed accomplishments that have emerged from first 20-years exploration of biomimetic study, including constructal theory, identified new scientific opportunities for further theoretical advances, examined how to effectively utilize the biomimetic results, including constructal theory, with new materials-innovation infrastructure, and discussed challenges in achieving the vision of accelerating the impact on industry and the nation's economy. This day-and-a-half workshop included leaders from industry and academia to discuss the state-of-the-art and possible future use of biomimetics, including constructal theory and design, to improve the health and well-being of the world’s population relative to energy, infrastructure, and water. Key research and engineering areas included heat and energy, water supply, biology, and health science disciplines. The workshop brought together experts across various fields to provide a focused effort in identify promising, key areas of future research.
